title: What's the average IQ of a school teacher? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can’t give you that number but I’ve seen analysis done by class rank and teachers are clearly not from the top ranks. First, that’s ok. It’s difficult to relate across standard deviations (IQ) to understand how difficulties appear in other people’s understanding of what you’re explaining! You don’t necessarily want the very brightest people teaching average people. Second, it’s an indicator of how desirable the job is. Let’s call it: the job generally sucks. It’s low pay, low prestige, high responsibilities and unstable nature means only some sort of highly motivated, high ideals kind of person would walk that road. So teachers are not, on the whole, the best and brightest, so what? They are often really fine people doing a really tough job. They deserve your respect. They earned their degree, they earned additional credits through training and often this leads to a masters degree. They are a long way from average! They are on your side, trying to teach what they really Do know. Thank them profusely or see them disappear leaving you with who or what…a viewing screen? IQ is not nearly as important or critical as people make it out to be. Hard work wins out. Teachers are hard working people! I understand the question seemed a simple one but it indicates in its simplicity a misplaced faith in a single measurement. I’ve tried to satisfy your curiosity while giving you a answer suitable to a poorly understood context. I’m trying to teach :-)

I think my IQ was 165 while the normal ranged between 85–115. I was first a child who went to school, then to the Army and ended up taking more than 120 courses while earning 2 bachelors, 2 masters and a DD. I worked in Compton where 85% of elementary teachers were black females who didn’t speak with correct subject verb agreement, ie, “I be going” so I would say on a racially-biased IQ test they would be on the low end of 85. However, seeing that their students were primarily blacks and Hispanics it took more of nurturing than IQ to motivate the students to learn, therefore I would say IQ is not a factor of being a teacher. As a matter of fact I think it might’ve been detrimental for me as I had ideas on how to improve the system and how to make it more cost effective; BA-Accounting and MBA. Something Compton didn’t want as they were $40 million in the hole which was supposed to be impossible.
